\doxysubsection{Detailed Description}
Circular singly linked list. 

\begin{DoxyCopyright}{Copyright}
Copyright 2013-\/2023 Marco Bacchi \href{mailto:marco@bacchi.at}{\texttt{ marco@bacchi.\+at}} 
\end{DoxyCopyright}
\begin{DoxyParagraph}{License\+:}
This file is released under the MIT License.~\newline
 \href{https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT}{\texttt{ https\+://opensource.\+org/licenses/\+MIT}}
\end{DoxyParagraph}
In computer science, a linked list is a linear collection of data elements, whose order is not given by their physical placement in memory. Instead, each element points to the next. It is a data structure consisting of a collection of nodes which together represent a sequence. In its most basic form, each node contains\+: data, and a reference (in other words, a link) to the next node in the sequence. This structure allows for efficient insertion or removal of elements from any position in the sequence during iteration. More info at \href{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linked_list}{\texttt{ https\+://en.\+wikipedia.\+org/wiki/\+Linked\+\_\+list}}

Singly linked lists contain nodes which have a data field as well as \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} field, which points to the next node in line of nodes. Operations that can be performed on singly linked lists include insertion, deletion, and traversal. More info at \href{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linked_list\#Singly_linked_list}{\texttt{ https\+://en.\+wikipedia.\+org/wiki/\+Linked\+\_\+list\#\+Singly\+\_\+linked\+\_\+list}}

In the last node of a list, the link field often contains a null reference, a special value used to indicate the lack of further nodes. A less common convention is to make it point to the first node of the list; in that case, the list is said to be \textquotesingle{}circular\textquotesingle{} or \textquotesingle{}circularly linked\textquotesingle{}; otherwise, it is said to be \textquotesingle{}open\textquotesingle{} or \textquotesingle{}linear\textquotesingle{}. It is a list where the last pointer points to the first node. More info at \href{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linked_list\#Circular_linked_list}{\texttt{ https\+://en.\+wikipedia.\+org/wiki/\+Linked\+\_\+list\#\+Circular\+\_\+linked\+\_\+list}}

Comparison Singly Linked List vs. Arrays\+:

\tabulinesep=1mm
\begin{longtabu}spread 0pt [c]{*{2}{|X[-1]}|}
\hline
\PBS\centering \cellcolor{\tableheadbgcolor}\textbf{ Arrays   }&\PBS\centering \cellcolor{\tableheadbgcolor}\textbf{ Singly Linked List    }\\\cline{1-2}
\endfirsthead
\hline
\endfoot
\hline
\PBS\centering \cellcolor{\tableheadbgcolor}\textbf{ Arrays   }&\PBS\centering \cellcolor{\tableheadbgcolor}\textbf{ Singly Linked List    }\\\cline{1-2}
\endhead
Arrays are stored in a continuous location.   &Linked lists are not stored in contiguous locations.    \\\cline{1-2}
Fixed size.   &Dynamic in size.    \\\cline{1-2}
Memory is allocated at compile time.   &Memory is allocated at run time (not necessarily true).    \\\cline{1-2}
Uses less memory than linked lists.   &Uses more memory because it stores both data and the address of the next node.    \\\cline{1-2}
Elements can be accessed easily.   &Insertion and deletion operations are faster.   \\\cline{1-2}
\end{longtabu}

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{slist\_begin}{slist\_begin}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \#define slist\+\_\+begin(\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{}]{slist }\end{DoxyParamCaption})~((slist)-\/$>$next)}



Returns an iterator to the beginning of a circular singly linked list. 

This macro provides an iterator pointing to the first element in a circular singly linked list. Since the head node of the list also serves as a part of the list, this macro returns the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer of the head node. If the list is empty (i.\+e., the head\textquotesingle{}s \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer points back to the head), this iterator will point to the head node itself, indicating that there are no elements in the list.

The {\ttfamily slist\+\_\+begin} macro is useful for accessing the first element of the list, especially when iterating over the list or performing operations on the elements. It is important to check if the list is empty before dereferencing the returned iterator.

\mbox{\Hypertarget{slist_8h_acf6bb9d48b1bf8d80d6a3ce855d6afd2}\label{slist_8h_acf6bb9d48b1bf8d80d6a3ce855d6afd2}}

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{slist\_clear}{slist\_clear}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \#define slist\+\_\+clear(\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{}]{slistptr }\end{DoxyParamCaption})~    \mbox{\hyperlink{slist_8h_aeadaebf6d4d904d4b7244643352f4850}{slist\+\_\+init}}(slistptr)}



Clears a circular singly linked list. 

This macro clears the contents of a circular singly linked list. It reinitializes the list by setting the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer of the head node to point to itself, effectively marking the list as empty. This operation resets the list to its initial state, with no nodes linked to the head.

It is important to note that this macro only resets the list structure; it does not free the memory associated with the nodes in the list. If the nodes were dynamically allocated, the user should ensure that they are properly freed before clearing the list to avoid memory leaks.

\mbox{\Hypertarget{slist_8h_a6b02a2ed9d13f16f44b09ead8135f34f}\label{slist_8h_a6b02a2ed9d13f16f44b09ead8135f34f}}

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{slist\_empty}{slist\_empty}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \#define slist\+\_\+empty(\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{}]{slist }\end{DoxyParamCaption})~((slist)-\/$>$next==(slist))}



Tests whether a circular singly linked list is empty. 

This macro checks if a circular singly linked list is empty by comparing the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer of the head node ({\ttfamily slist}) to the address of the head node itself. In an empty circular singly linked list, the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer of the head node points to the head node, indicating that there are no other nodes in the list. This quick check allows for determining if the list contains any elements without traversing the list.

It is particularly useful for checking the state of the list before performing operations that require the list to contain elements.

Usage\+:

\mbox{\Hypertarget{slist_8h_a4a55ae00593db3acc4726b9cf6bdfe98}\label{slist_8h_a4a55ae00593db3acc4726b9cf6bdfe98}}

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{slist\_end}{slist\_end}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \#define slist\+\_\+end(\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{}]{slist }\end{DoxyParamCaption})~(slist)}



Returns an iterator to the past-\/the-\/end element in a circular singly linked list. 

This macro provides an iterator referring to the past-\/the-\/end element in a circular singly linked list. The past-\/the-\/end element is a theoretical element that follows the last element in the list. It is not a valid element and thus shall not be dereferenced. This iterator is commonly used in combination with {\ttfamily slist\+\_\+begin} to specify a range that includes all the elements in the container.

In a circular singly linked list, the past-\/the-\/end element is represented by the list node itself. As such, this macro returns the list node, signifying the end of the list. This is particularly useful for loop conditions and iterator comparisons where a sentinel value is needed to represent the end of the list.

Usage\+:

\mbox{\Hypertarget{slist_8h_aa0773a47d8b00e244e5df9836c14a3b4}\label{slist_8h_aa0773a47d8b00e244e5df9836c14a3b4}}

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{slist\_erase}{slist\_erase}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \#define slist\+\_\+erase(\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{}]{slistptr,  }\item[{}]{nodeptr }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}

{\bfseries Value\+:}
\begin{DoxyCode}{0}
\DoxyCodeLine{    \textcolor{keywordflow}{do}\{                                                                             \(\backslash\)}
\DoxyCodeLine{        slist\_prev(slistptr,nodeptr)-\/>next = ((\mbox{\hyperlink{structslist__node__t}{slist\_node\_t}}*)(nodeptr))-\/>next;      \(\backslash\)}
\DoxyCodeLine{    \}\textcolor{keywordflow}{while}(0)}

\end{DoxyCode}


Removes a specific node from a circular singly linked list. 

This macro removes a specified node ({\ttfamily nodeptr}) from the circular singly linked list. It accomplishes this by finding the node that precedes {\ttfamily nodeptr} in the list using {\ttfamily slist\+\_\+prev(slistptr, nodeptr)} and then adjusting its \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer to bypass {\ttfamily nodeptr}, pointing instead to the node that follows {\ttfamily nodeptr}. This operation effectively removes {\ttfamily nodeptr} from the list.

The operation requires finding the previous node, which involves a partial traversal of the list up to {\ttfamily nodeptr}. It is important to ensure that {\ttfamily nodeptr} is a valid and existing member of the list before using this macro. Improper usage may lead to undefined behavior.

Note that this macro only removes {\ttfamily nodeptr} from the list structure; it does not free the memory associated with {\ttfamily nodeptr}. If {\ttfamily nodeptr} was dynamically allocated, users are responsible for managing its memory.

Usage\+:

Iterates through all elements in a circular singly linked list. 

This macro sets up a loop that iterates from the first to the last element in a circular singly linked list. It initializes the iterator to the first element in the list using {\ttfamily slist\+\_\+begin}, and then continues to iterate over each element until it reaches the end of the list, indicated by {\ttfamily slist\+\_\+end}. This macro is useful for performing operations on each element in the list, such as searching, modifying, or printing values.

The macro uses a for loop to traverse the list, making it easy to apply a block of code to each element. It is important to ensure that the list is properly initialized before using this macro to avoid undefined behavior.

Retrieves the first element in a circular singly linked list. 

This macro provides access to the first data-\/containing node in a circular singly linked list. It utilizes the {\ttfamily slist\+\_\+begin} macro to obtain an iterator pointing to the first element. If the list is empty, this iterator will point back to the head node itself, which should not be treated as a valid data-\/containing node.

The {\ttfamily slist\+\_\+front} macro simplifies accessing the first element of the list. Users should verify that the list is not empty before attempting to use the returned iterator to access list data.

Initializes a circular singly linked list. 

This macro initializes a circular singly linked list. It sets up the list such that the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer of the head node points to the head itself, indicating an empty list. In a circular singly linked list, this condition signifies that there are no other nodes in the list, and the list loops back to the head. This initialization is crucial for the proper functioning of the list, as it establishes the fundamental circular structure of the list.

Proper initialization of the list is essential before performing any other operations on the list, as it ensures that the list is in a known and empty state.

Inserts a node after a specified position in a circular singly linked list. 

This macro inserts a new node ({\ttfamily nodeptr}) into the circular singly linked list immediately after a specified node ({\ttfamily posptr}). The insertion is achieved by adjusting the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer of {\ttfamily nodeptr} to point to the node that follows {\ttfamily posptr}, and then updating the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer of {\ttfamily posptr} to point to {\ttfamily nodeptr}. This operation effectively places {\ttfamily nodeptr} into the list directly after {\ttfamily posptr}.

The operation is efficient as it only involves modifying the pointers of {\ttfamily posptr} and {\ttfamily nodeptr}, without the need to traverse the entire list. It is crucial that both {\ttfamily posptr} and {\ttfamily nodeptr} are valid pointers to nodes and that {\ttfamily posptr} is an existing member of the list for the macro to function correctly. Improper usage may lead to undefined behavior.

Inserts a node before a specified position in a circular singly linked list. 

This macro inserts a new node ({\ttfamily nodeptr}) into the circular singly linked list immediately before a specified node ({\ttfamily posptr}). The insertion is achieved by adjusting the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer of the node that precedes {\ttfamily posptr}, found using {\ttfamily slist\+\_\+prev(slist, posptr)}, to point to {\ttfamily nodeptr}, and then setting the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer of {\ttfamily nodeptr} to {\ttfamily posptr}. This operation effectively places {\ttfamily nodeptr} into the list directly before {\ttfamily posptr}.

The operation requires finding the previous node, which involves a partial traversal of the list up to {\ttfamily posptr}. This macro assumes that both {\ttfamily posptr} and {\ttfamily nodeptr} are valid pointers to nodes and that {\ttfamily posptr} is an existing member of the list. Improper usage may lead to undefined behavior.

Removes the last element from a circular singly linked list. 

This macro removes the last element in the circular singly linked list. It locates the node that is two positions behind the head node (which is effectively the last node) using {\ttfamily slist\+\_\+prev\+\_\+prev(slist, slist)}, and then sets its \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer to point to the head node ({\ttfamily slist}). This operation removes the last node from the list.

Since this operation requires finding the second-\/to-\/last node, it involves traversing almost the entire list, which makes it less efficient, particularly for longer lists. The macro assumes that the list contains at least one element other than the head node. Users should check that the list is not empty before performing this operation to avoid undefined behavior.

Removes the first element from a circular singly linked list. 

This macro removes the first element in the circular singly linked list. It does this by setting the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer of the head node ({\ttfamily slist}) to point to the second node in the list, effectively removing the first node from the list. This operation is efficient as it requires only a modification of the head node\textquotesingle{}s \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer.

It is important to ensure that the list is not empty before calling this macro. If the list is empty (i.\+e., {\ttfamily slist-\/$>$next} is {\ttfamily slist}), calling {\ttfamily slist\+\_\+pop\+\_\+front} will have no effect. Users should also handle memory management for the removed node if it was dynamically allocated. This macro only removes the node from the list structure; it does not free the memory associated with the node.

Inserts an element at the end of a circular singly linked list. 

This macro inserts a new node ({\ttfamily node\+\_\+to\+\_\+add}) at the end of the circular singly linked list. It first finds the current last node in the list using {\ttfamily slist\+\_\+back(slist)}, which traverses the entire list. Once the last node is identified, the macro sets the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer of this node to {\ttfamily node\+\_\+to\+\_\+add}, and then adjusts the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer of {\ttfamily node\+\_\+to\+\_\+add} to point to the head of the list ({\ttfamily slist}), maintaining the circular nature of the list.

This operation requires traversing the entire list to find the last node, which has a linear time complexity with respect to the number of elements in the list. Users should ensure that {\ttfamily node\+\_\+to\+\_\+add} is properly allocated and initialized before using this macro.

Inserts an element at the beginning of a circular singly linked list. 

This macro inserts a new node ({\ttfamily node\+\_\+to\+\_\+add}) at the beginning of the circular singly linked list, right after the head node. The insertion is achieved by setting the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer of {\ttfamily node\+\_\+to\+\_\+add} to the current first element of the list, and then updating the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer of the head node ({\ttfamily slist}) to point to {\ttfamily node\+\_\+to\+\_\+add}. After the insertion, {\ttfamily node\+\_\+to\+\_\+add} becomes the new first element in the list.

This operation is efficient as it does not require traversing the list and directly modifies the necessary pointers to insert the new node. It is important to ensure that {\ttfamily node\+\_\+to\+\_\+add} is properly allocated and initialized before using this macro.

{\footnotesize\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{slist_8h_ac626c3ba7de6d820620343dfc50fd279}{slist\+\_\+t}}}



Typedef for the circular singly linked list. 

List instance is also a member of the list

This typedef is used to define a type for the circular singly linked list. It establishes {\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{structslist__node__t}{slist\+\_\+node\+\_\+t}}} as the type for the head of the list. In a circular singly linked list defined by this typedef, the head node itself is a member of the list, pointing to the first data-\/containing node or back to itself if the list is empty. This setup simplifies certain list operations by providing a consistent starting point for list traversal and manipulation.

Usage\+:

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{slist\_back()}{slist\_back()}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{structslist__node__t}{slist\+\_\+node\+\_\+t}}$\ast$ slist\+\_\+back (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{\mbox{\hyperlink{slist_8h_ac626c3ba7de6d820620343dfc50fd279}{slist\+\_\+t}} $\ast$}]{slist }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Returns the last node in a circular singly linked list. 

This function searches for the last node in a circular singly linked list. It starts from the end of the list, which is the head node itself (represented by {\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{slist_8h_a4a55ae00593db3acc4726b9cf6bdfe98}{slist\+\_\+end(slist)}}}), and iterates through the list until it finds a node whose \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer points back to the head node. This node is identified as the last node in the list.

This approach is necessary because the list is singly linked and does not have direct pointers to previous nodes. The function is useful for operations that require access to the last element of the list, such as appending elements or performing certain modifications.

\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}
The function assumes that the list is properly initialized. If the list is empty, the function will return the head node itself. The function has linear time complexity, as it may need to traverse the entire list to find the last node.
\end{DoxyNote}

\mbox{\Hypertarget{slist_8h_a50bb2ab18efd8562fbc4882346d74f2c}\label{slist_8h_a50bb2ab18efd8562fbc4882346d74f2c}}

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{slist\_find()}{slist\_find()}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{structslist__node__t}{slist\+\_\+node\+\_\+t}}$\ast$ slist\+\_\+find (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{\mbox{\hyperlink{slist_8h_ac626c3ba7de6d820620343dfc50fd279}{slist\+\_\+t}} $\ast$}]{slist,  }\item[{void $\ast$}]{node }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Searches for a specific node in a circular singly linked list. 

This function iterates through the circular singly linked list to find a specified node ({\ttfamily node}). The search is conducted by comparing each node\textquotesingle{}s address in the list with the address of {\ttfamily node}. If the specified node is found in the list, the function returns a pointer to that node; otherwise, it returns NULL.

The search uses the {\ttfamily slist\+\_\+foreach} macro to traverse each node in the list. This function is useful for verifying whether a specific node is present in the list and for operations that depend on locating a particular node within the list.

\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}
The function runs in linear time complexity with respect to the number of elements in the list. It is important to ensure that the list is properly initialized before using this function.
\end{DoxyNote}

\mbox{\Hypertarget{slist_8h_a251765371febfc140be13cb5b785267d}\label{slist_8h_a251765371febfc140be13cb5b785267d}}

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{slist\_prev()}{slist\_prev()}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{structslist__node__t}{slist\+\_\+node\+\_\+t}}$\ast$ slist\+\_\+prev (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{\mbox{\hyperlink{slist_8h_ac626c3ba7de6d820620343dfc50fd279}{slist\+\_\+t}} $\ast$}]{slist,  }\item[{void $\ast$}]{existing\+\_\+node }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Finds the previous node in a circular singly linked list. 

This function searches for the node that precedes a specified node ({\ttfamily node}) in a circular singly linked list. Since the list is singly linked, the function traverses the list starting from the specified node and continues until it loops back to the same node. The node immediately before this loop-\/back is the predecessor of the given node.

This traversal is necessary due to the singly linked nature of the list, as there are no direct pointers to previous nodes. The function is useful for operations that require knowledge of a node\textquotesingle{}s predecessor, such as certain insertion or deletion operations.

\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}
The function assumes that both the list and the node are properly initialized. If the node is not part of the list, the behavior is undefined. This function has a linear time complexity with respect to the number of elements in the list.
\end{DoxyNote}

\mbox{\Hypertarget{slist_8h_ab2b4d20ae442d1ad98748fafae052c32}\label{slist_8h_ab2b4d20ae442d1ad98748fafae052c32}}

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{slist\_prev\_prev()}{slist\_prev\_prev()}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{structslist__node__t}{slist\+\_\+node\+\_\+t}}$\ast$ slist\+\_\+prev\+\_\+prev (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{\mbox{\hyperlink{slist_8h_ac626c3ba7de6d820620343dfc50fd279}{slist\+\_\+t}} $\ast$}]{slist,  }\item[{void $\ast$}]{node }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Finds the node two steps behind a specified node in a circular singly linked list. 

This function searches for the node that is two positions before a specified node ({\ttfamily node}) in a circular singly linked list. It traverses the list, checking for the node whose \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} node\textquotesingle{}s \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer equals the specified node. If the specified node is at the beginning of the list, or the list does not contain enough elements, the function returns the list node itself, which is a well-\/defined behavior for this list structure.

This function is useful in operations where the node two steps behind a given node needs to be identified, such as certain deletion operations. Due to the singly linked nature of the list, the function iterates through the list to find the appropriate node.

\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}
This function has a linear time complexity with respect to the number of elements in the list. It is important to ensure that the list is properly initialized and the node is a part of the list.
\end{DoxyNote}

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{slist\_size()}{slist\_size()}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily size\+\_\+t slist\+\_\+size (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{\mbox{\hyperlink{slist_8h_ac626c3ba7de6d820620343dfc50fd279}{slist\+\_\+t}} $\ast$}]{slist }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Counts the number of nodes in a circular singly linked list. 

This function calculates and returns the number of elements (nodes) present in a circular singly linked list, excluding the head node itself. It traverses the list starting from the first element after the head node and counts each node until it reaches the head node again.

The traversal makes use of the {\ttfamily slist\+\_\+foreach} macro, which iterates over each node in the list. The function is useful for determining the size of the list for various operations such as allocation, serialization, or applying algorithms that depend on the number of elements.

\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}
The function assumes that the list is properly initialized. An uninitialized or improperly formed list might lead to undefined behavior. The function runs in linear time complexity, as it traverses each element of the list.
\end{DoxyNote}
